StoredProcedureSqlServerv2k5.name: [InsertUpdatePgSentEvent]
StoredProcedureSqlServerv2k5.body:
@EventId uniqueidentifier, @Ac.onDate date.me, @Ac.onDatePrecision smallint = null
AS BEGIN
-- STEP 1: Start the transac.on BEGIN TRANSACTION
-- STEP 2 & 3: Issue the data change statement(s), checking @@ERROR a.er each statement IF EXISTS(SELECT ID FROM [RSSOSS].[USMC].[PGSentEvent] WHERE ID = @EventId) BEGIN -- if @intCount > 0, then the Record already exists. UPDATE. UPDATE [RSSOSS].[USMC].[PGSentEvent] SET Ac.onDate = @Ac.onDate, Ac.onDatePrecision = @Ac.onDatePrecision WHERE ID = @EventId
END ELSE BEGIN -- if @intCount = 0, then the Record does not exist. INSERT. INSERT INTO [RSSOSS].[USMC].[PGSentEvent] ([ID] ,[Ac.onDate] ,[Ac.onDatePrecision]) VALUES (@EventId ,@Ac.onDate ,@Ac.onDatePrecision)
END
-- Rollback the transac.on if there were any errors IF @@ERROR <> 0 BEGIN -- Rollback the transac.on ROLLBACK TRANSACTION
-- Raise an error and return RAISERROR ('Error occurred while performing the change.', 16, 1) RETURN END
-- Rollback the transac.on if the number of rows changed does not meet our expecta.on... IF @@ROWCOUNT > 1 BEGIN -- Rollback the transac.on ROLLBACK TRANSACTION
-- Raise an error and return RAISERROR ('An unexpected number of rows were changed.', 16, 1) RETURN END
-- STEP 4: If we reach this point, the commands completed successfully -- Commit the transac.on.... COMMIT TRANSACTION
END
